body: I'm sympathetic to this perspective, but I'm really unhappy about how complex it is for users to solve a common request: "please just run my app headless for a server or CI" state. Without this type, controlling this with plugin disabling and/or feature flags currently requires pretty arcane knowledge of the every plugin and feature flag in Bevy.

we could add a feature group for headless that would enable the feature flags one would expect for that and call those "feature profiles"

We could even make ones for "basic 2d", "basic 3d" and "headless" that would just be subset of the default features

some day, the editor will expose something like this screen from Godot:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/341ab3e0-928b-4ad3-b11d-3d788335820d)


As an example, here is the list of features I tend to use for 2d games:
```
    "bevy_asset",
    "bevy_audio",
    "bevy_core_pipeline",
    "bevy_render",
    "bevy_sprite",
    "bevy_state",
    "bevy_text",
    "bevy_ui",
    "bevy_winit",
    "multi_threaded",
    "vorbis",
    "png",
    "webgl2",
    "x11",
```

Excellent issue, I'm not using headless plugins but it will be great if the compile-time of CI/server side projects will compile faster and will have less bloat in the final binaries (that also concerns games with visuals, please track your dependencies & its features, guys). In the current state of rust, its linker cannot predict with absolute precision which dependencies won't be used at runtime, so I think only 85% of the final binary will contain the code you really need if you import too heavy dependencies without setting the only features you need.

https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/pull/15260 needs release notes for the upcoming Bevy release!

Please reply below if you'd like to write these notes. 
While the author(s) of the PR often have the context, knowledge and motivation to draft the release notes for their feature, anyone can contribute release notes!

------

Release notes should:

1. Clearly motivate the change.
2. Be written in a way that is understandable by the average Bevy user: some programming background and a general understanding of games.
3. Show off the coolest features of the PR. Screenshots are awesome, but elegant APIs are also welcome!
4. If this was a perf-centric PR, quantify the performance improvements. Graphs and statistics work well for this.

We can help you revise the release notes: a rough draft alone is incredibly useful :)
Your expertise is invaluable for contextualizing the changes; we'll work with you to bring the technical writing up to par.

To submit your release notes, modify `/home/alice/Documents/bevy-website/release-content/0.15/release-notes/15260_Added_HeadlessPlugins_15203.md` and submit a PR.
In that PR, please mention this issue with the `Fixes #ISSUE_NUMBER` keyphrase so it gets closed automatically.
